awd_titl_txt: RUI:   Algebraic and Geometric Aspects of Matroids, Polytopes, and Arrangements
awd_abstract_narration:
This research project is driven by the philosophy that many objects and relationships in mathematics are best understood by studying the rich discrete structures underlying them. In the last few decades, combinatorics has grown and matured immensely as a field, in response to the mathematical needs of modern computing and the computational needs of all fields of mathematics. This project studies central questions in algebra and geometry where the combinatorial structure of high-dimensional geometric objects plays a crucial role, and offers unexpected, innovative approaches to long-standing problems. This research program constitutes the academic backbone of the San Francisco State University-Colombia Combinatorics Initiative, a vibrant research and training collaboration among primarily undergraduate institutions in the U.S. and Colombia. Through research-based courses, vertically and geographically integrated research projects, and the biannual Encuentro Colombiano de Combinatoria, students participate in a truly international cooperation while making substantial scientific contributions to combinatorics. Since 2007 the initiative has trained more than 200 pre-Ph.D. students, more than half of whom are members of underrepresented groups in mathematics, and more than 50 of whom have gone onto Ph.D. programs. The initiative also helps train mathematicians worldwide through the distribution of course videos, lecture notes, and research projects.

This project studies important questions in various fields of mathematics, such as representation theory (Kostant partition functions), enumerative geometry (moduli spaces of curves), polyhedral number theory (Ehrhart polynomials), Brunn-Minkowski theory (valuations of polytopes), Hopf-Lie theory (algebraic structures on polytopes), tropical geometry (tropical linear spaces, moduli spaces, and Hodge theory), total positivity (positroids and their algebraic structure), and combinatorial commutative algebra (Fröberg's conjecture). These subjects are related in surprising ways, and the techniques from one field become powerful tools in the others. At the heart of many of these questions lies a configuration of vectors -- often a root system -- that plays an essential role. The combinatorial theories of polytopes, (Coxeter) matroids, and hyperplane arrangements are designed to study these configurations, and the powerful toolkit that they offer is the unifying thread of this project. Solutions to the problems under study will have a strong impact in combinatorics and discrete geometry, and will further our understanding of central questions in algebra and geometry.

por.por_cntn:
This work was driven by the philosophy that many objects, relationships, and procedures in pure and applied mathematics are best understood by studying the rich discrete structures underlying them. A few of the main contributions are the following:

1. A proof of Brylawski and Dawson's conjecture from the 1980s on the shape of certain sequences of numbers arising from combinatorial geometry: the h-vector of a matroid is unimodal and log-concave. This was done by discovering a new geometric model for matroids and understanding its combinatorial and algebro-geometric structure.

2. A research monograph on the algebraic structure of a family of polytopes (generalized permutahedra). In a unified framework, this work solved many open problems and unified many classic results in combinatorial Hopf algebras. It also answered a 2005 question of Loday on the connection between algebraic operations on power series and the geometry of the associahedron.

3. A description of the equivariant Ehrhart theory of the permutahedron, solving a 2010 problem posed by Stapledon. This measures a very important family of symmetric polytopes, while taking into account its symmetries.

4. An extension of the theory of submodular functions -- which is central in optimizaiton -- to problems with symmetries controlled by a reflection group. This provides a tool for solving optimization problems with symmetries, and it describes how the Coxeter permutahedron can be deformed into more intricate geometric shapes.

5. The construction of a family of highly symmetric tropical surfaces, and formulas for the eigenvalues of its tropical Laplacians. This confirms a prediction of Babaae and Huh on the sign of these eigenvalues.

6. The development of efficient algorithms to move robots optimally by using the combinatorial structure of their "maps of possibilities", which have the geometric structure of CAT(0) cube complexes.

 

BROADER IMPACTS.

This research program served as the mathematical backbone of the SFSU-Colombia Combinatorics Initiative, which works to build and support an increasingly diverse, engaged, and active community of mathematicians that serves the needs of all sectors of society. Through joint activities and research projects, students in the US and Colombia participated in their first international academic experience, while making serious scientific contributions. The results of this work and lessons learned have been highlighted nationally at various meetings and publications of the American Math Society, presented at numerous panels and seminars, and shared with science faculty across San Francisco State University.

During this three-year period, the project provided direct research opportunities to over 35 students. The PI directly advised one postdoc, 3 PhD student, 8 Master's thesis students, and 2 undergraduate researchers; they were all involved in research projects which were or will be submitted for publication. Additionally, 24 undergraduate and Master's students carried out 8 miniresearch projects in combinatorics. More than half of the students were women, and more than half were members of US ethnic underrepresented groups.

About 140 additional participants were involved in the project through their participation in the biannual Encuentros Colombianos de Combinatoria. Hundreds of others around the world are involved indirectly, through an online archive of videos in graduate combinatorics developed under this grant.
